author: sky.cactus
content: I am of the opinion that the gas limit is already way too high and should be dialed way back.  At the least, we should not increase it for a long time to get things back under control.

author: sky.cactus
content: State expiry and regenesis may help us undo the damage caused by the historically high gas limit, and the portal network may be able to mitigate a significant portion of the negative effects of the excessively high gas limit.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, until those things are all built and we can see their impact I am pretty strongly against any gas limit increases.

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO, we should be targeting consumer grade hardware that does things other than just running an Ethereum client.  This means that the average person who buys a laptop or desktop from a big box computer store will be able to run an Ethereum client along side their normal day to day software like watching videos, gaming, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently, this is not reasonably possible due to the storage space requirements of Ethereum, which is (I believe) directly proportional to the gas limit.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think Ethereum layer 1 should strive to be maximally censorship resistant.  We live in a world of increasing censorship and the entire purpose of using a blockchain is to provide a mechanism to protect users from that censorship.  If you don't care about censorship resistance, there are *many* far better solutions out there than a blockchain, and if you believe that the censors won't come after you if you just put "blockchain" in the name then there are many other blockchains you can use that will meet that qualification.

author: sky.cactus
content: To achieve maximum censorship resistance, Ethereum needs to be operable by any individual user of the network without needing to trust a centralized third party.  The reason for this is because censorship historically has always targeted centralized entities.  Censors very rarely go after individuals because that is way too hard and people push back too much against that.  Instead, you target centralized data providers who are much easier for a censor to target and control.

author: sky.cactus
content: Bittorrent is incredibly resillient to censorship because it is so trivially easy to run a bittorrent client on any computer and connect up to a global mesh network.  The one "centralized" piece is the tracker, but the operating cost of a tracker is so low that if it gets targeted you can trivially move it somewhere else and you don't suffer any significant costs for that migration.

author: sky.cactus
content:
There is a famous story about how an Indian government rewarded people for bringing in the heads of cobras in an attempt to lower the cobra population (which was causing problems).  What this lead to was people spinning up cobra breeding farms to collect the reward.  Once the government realized this, they stopped the program and those bred cobras were released into the wild, so the net effect of the program was an increase in the cobra population.

The moral of the story is that you need to be very careful with aligning incentives with the behavior you want.  It is very easy to create an incentive that achieves the opposite of your goal.
